meta.title: Dissecting the critical stage in the response of maize kernel set to individual and combined drought and heat stress around flowering
meta.author: Xiwei Liu, Xinglong Wang, Xingya Wang, Jia Gao, Ning Luo, Qingfeng Meng, Pu Wang

div.text: Increases in frequency and magnitude of drought and heat events are the prime abiotic constraints, which cause considerable adverse effects on maize kernel set and grain yield. However, there is little information about a comprehensive and systematical understanding to identify the critical stage in the response of kernel numbers per spike (KNS) to individual and combined drought and heat stress around flowering. Here we evaluated three successive phases (florets development, florets pollination and seed setting) of kernel set under drought, heat and combined drought and heat stress (DS, HS and DHS) with two maize hybrids using the field site ponds covered with a rain shelter in 2018 and 2019. As an average in two years, KNS was reduced by 18.9 % in DS treatment, 10.8 % in HS treatment and 37.2 % in DHS treatment compared with the control treatment. The most considerable adverse impacts during the three phases were all observed in DHS treatment, followed by DS and HS treatments. Among the three phases, the impact of stress on seed setting was more substantial than that in the other two phases for both hybrids. Kernel abortion was the main reason for the decrease in KNS due to the stress, which resulted from the prevention of sugar-starch conversion. The starch content in the kernel was reduced by 42 % in DS treatment, 29 % in HS treatment and 58 % in DHS treatment on the 8th day after silking. This finding would supply a reference for breeders to evolve strategies in developing stress-resilient and high-yielding hybrids under climate change.

As the leading food crops in the world, maize (Zea mays L.) accounted for 42 % of cereal production (FAO, 2019). Maize yield is frequently limited when suffered from the individual or the combined abiotic stresses in future climates (Lesk et al., 2016). Increases in frequency and magnitude of drought and heat stresses are the prime abiotic constraints that cause considerable adverse effects on maize production (Lobell and Field, 2007;Velde et al., 2010;Hatfield et al., 2011). Maize yield is determined by the harvested kernel numbers per unit land area and average kernel weight. Kernel numbers per spike (KNS) is responsible for most yield variation for a given plant density (Andrade et al., 1999;Borrás and Vitantonio-Mazzini et al., 2018). Understanding the impacts and the underlying mechanism of drought, heat and their combination on kernel set is of utmost importance for guiding maize breeding and management to offset predicted yield losses in the face of climate change.

The KNS is established during the flowering period (Borrás and Vitantonio-Mazzini, 2018). The formation of final KNS needs three consecutive processes (i.e., the florets differentiation, florets pollination and seed setting) (Edreira et al., 2011), all of which are sensitive to abiotic stresses (Hatfield et al., 2011;Prasad et al., 2017). Any one of the above processes suffered from abiotic stresses would lead to decreased kernel numbers (Edreira et al., 2011). Potential KNS is established early during vegetative growth stage (around the eight-leaf stage, Gonzalez et al., 2019). This potential KNS is reduced around flowering during which time plants undergo pivotal growth events such as tassel and silk growth, pollination, fertilization and subsequently seed setting (Sánchez et al., 2014;Shen et al., 2020). Stress factors such as drought and heat around the flowering stage could affect these growth events and contribute to the eventual reproductive failure (Barnabás et al., 2008;Oury et al., 2016b). Although many of studies have focused on one or several processes to determine the final KNS (Edreira et al., 2011;Siebers et al., 2017), there is little information about a comprehensive and systematical understanding to identify the critical stage in the response of maize kernel set with drought and heat stress around flowering.

Some independent studies have demonstrated the effects of drought and heat stress on KNS. Drought stress around flowering reduced the silk and ovary growth rate (Oury et al., 2016a, b), extended anthesis-silking interval (Edmeades et al., 2000;Fuad-hassan et al., 2008), and reduced the silk receptivity (Bassetti and Westgate, 1993). For heat stress, it decreased the ability of pollen germination (Dupuis and Dumas, 1990), pollen tube elongation (Stone, 2001), and altered pollen morphology (i.e., thicker exine wall and disintegrated tapetum layer) (Djanaguiraman et al., 2018). In the maize field, drought and heat stress often occurred in combination (Wang et al., 2018). The simultaneous occurrence of both stresses increased the deleterious effect, such that the effect considerably exceeded the simple additive effects of the action alone (Zandalinas et al., 2018). However, the interactive effects of both stresses around flowering on KNS of maize have received far less attention.

Most previous researches on the impacts of drought and heat stress on maize KNS were carried out in the greenhouse with pot experiments, which may hide important agronomic traits in the field and has limited understanding of the actual agricultural production (Mittler, 2006).

Here we prevented precipitation effects with a dry pool covered with a half-electric rain shelter and increased the temperature with the polyethylene film (100 μm thickness) mounted on steel structures of 3.5 m height in the field. We investigated the response of floret numbers, florets pollination and seed setting in two maize hybrids with different genetic backgrounds (hybrids from temperate and cool-temperate) to drought, heat and the combined stress around flowering (Fig. 1A). We try to (І) identify which process (i.e., the florets development, pollination and seed setting) would impact the KNS mostly due to the stress, and (Ⅱ) determine which of these three processes predominates for each type of stress (HS, DS, DHS) through using different hybrids.

The experiment was conducted in 2018 and 2019 under a halfelectric rain shelter at the Shangzhuang Experimental Station of China Agricultural University, Beijing, China, (40°08′ N, 116°10′ E). The halfelectric rain shelter contained 16 big ponds (2 m long, 4 m wide, and 1.8 m deep) and 16 small ponds (2 m long, 2 m wide, and 1.8 m deep). Each pond was cemented on the four sides and the bottom, and filled with calcareous fluro-aquic soil. The top 20 cm soils were sampled before sowing with total nitrogen 0.75 g kg -1 in 2018 and 0.81 g kg -1 in 2019, organic matter 12.36 g kg -1 in 2018 and 12.88 g kg -1 in 2019, rapid available phosphorus 83.88 mg kg -1 in 2018 and 87.55 mg kg -1 in 2019, rapid available potassium 100.16 mg kg -1 in 2018 and 100.47 mg kg -1 in 2019, and soil bulk density 1.30 g cm -3 in 2018 and 1.35 g cm -3 in 2019. Before sowing, 120 kg N ha -1 , 50 kg P 2 O 5 ha -1 , and 150 kg K 2 O ha -1 was applied evenly to the soil surface, then turned the ground over. The additional 120 kg N ha -1 was applied by furrowing at the twelve-leaf stage. Weeds, pests, and diseases were well controlled during the crop growing season.

Treatments consisted of a completely randomized block design of two hybrids and four treatments with four replications. Two hybrids (Zhengdan 958 and Demeiya 1) were selected for representing different cropping regions. Zhengdan 958 is a long season maize cultivar commonly grown in the North China Plain (temperate region), while the Demeiya 1 was developed in Heilongjiang Province, China, at high latitudes (> 47 °N) (cool-temperate region). The ponds were maintained under different stress conditions from tasseling to seed setting (Fig. 1A).
(1) Control treatment (well-irrigated, CK). The temperature followed the natural condition. The soil water potential was -0.11 ∼ -0.15 MPa.

(2) Drought-stress (DS) treatment. A water deficit was introduced by no irrigation about five days before tasseling and the soil water potential was -0.41 ∼ -0.53 MPa. (3) Heat-stress (HS) treatment. The equipment with elevated temperature was according to the method of Savin et al. (1996). The polyethylene film (100 μm thickness) was mounted on steel structures of 3.5 m height (as shown in Fig. 1E), while leaving the bottom 50 cm of the four sides of each structure open and the top 30 cm open in order to facilitate free gas exchange from top to bottom. (4) Combined drought and heat stress (DHS) treatment. The method for combined drought and heat stress was according to treatment (2) and (3).

The drought and heat stress started when 50 % of the plants reached tasseling (2∼3 cm of visible tassel). The stress treatments were finished at the end of the seed setting. The soil water potential was recorded by Em50 (Decagon model MPS-6, ICT International, Washington, American). The soil water sensor (MPS-6) could measure the moisture content of porous materials and convert the moisture content into soil water potential according to the water release curve. The sensors of Em50 were buried 40 cm underground of each plot. The canopy air temperature was measured by GSP-6 data loggers (Jiangsu Jingchuang Electronics Co., Ltd., GB, Jiangsu, China). The sensors of GSP-6 were placed in the center of each plot at the uppermost ear level (Fig. 1D). As an average in two years, the daily mean temperature increased by 3.7℃ for Zhengdan 958 and by 3.9℃ for Demeiya 1 in HS treatment (Supplemental Table S1). Furthermore, a similar temperature increase trend compared with CK during the three phases was also observed (Supplemental Table S2, S3 and S4). The row spacing was 60 cm with plant spacing of 20 cm. At physiological maturity, Zhengdan 958 was harvested on October 1 in 2018 and October 8 in 2019, and Demeiya 1 was harvested on September 1 in 2018 and September 10 in 2019.

Twenty uniform maize plants were tagged in each replication of the treatment before tasseling in 2018 and 2019. The dates of anthesis (i.e. at least one anther started shedding pollen) and silking (i.e. silk emerged 1∼2 cm) were recorded. The anthesis-silking interval (ASI) was calculated as the difference between the anthesis date and silking date. Four plants of each treatment were used for silk growth dynamics. Exposed silks were cut from the apical ear and weighted to develop a cumulative curve of silk emergence until no silk was visible at 9:00 am. The fresh pollen from four plants in four treatments was collected between 9:30-10:00 am at the blossoming date (i.e. the maximum pollen shedding number), then stained with 0.5 % triphenyl tetrazolium chloride on microslide. The pollen grains were observed and photographed with a stereomicroscope (Olympus SZX7, Japan) after 20 min. The red pollen grains were regarded as viable and the rest were unviable. Pollen viability was obtained as the percentage between viable pollen numbers and the total pollen numbers per microscopic field (Wang et al., 2019).

paragraphs.title: Florets differentiation, fertilization and seed setting

div.text: Five uniform maize plants were tagged, and the ears were bagged to avoid pollination before silk emergence. The plants were pollinated with fresh pollen from the same treatment for three successive days to ensure that all silks were pollinated. The two hand-pollinated ears were harvested after 7 days of silking and the exposed silks were counted in 2019. The husk tissues were gently removed in case of to prevent breaking the ovary-silk junctions, to allow a clear view of successive flowers and silks along the ear, then shook slightly. Both falling and withered silks in ovary-silk junction were recorded as the number of fertilized floret. The fresh silk that was not drop out was counted as the number of unfertilized florets. Meanwhile, the number of florets without silking was counted. The total number of floret differentiation was the sum of fertilized and unfertilized florets and florets without silking. The other three hand-pollinated ears were harvested after 20 days of silking, and the seed number per ear was counted. The number of kernel abortion was the difference between the numbers of fertilized florets and seeds. At physiology maturity (i.e. visible black layer), four plants were harvested and the final kernel numbers were counted.

paragraphs.title: The plant biomass and the proportion partitioned to ear by 13 C isotope labeling

div.text: The four uniform maize plants per treatment were tagged and the ear leaf was fed with 13 CO 2 (99 atom %) at 10: 00 a.m. on the 8th day after silking (DAS) in 2019. The leaf was enclosed in a transparent polythene bag that has a similar leaf size, and the bag was sealed at the leaf bottom with waterproof tape to prevent gas leakage. Afterward, 50 mL 13 CO 2 was injected into the bag, and the bag was removed from the leaf one hour later. The maize plants labeled with 13 C above-ground parts were harvested. The shoot was divided into stem, leaf, sheath, husk and ear. All tissues were dried for constant weight at 60℃ and weighed. Then the tissue pulverized to pass a 1 mm screen and 1 mg samples were weighed to measure 13 C concentration using a Stable Isotope Analyser (Vario El, Germany) (Schmidt and Scrimgeour, 2001). The remaining powder of the tissue was used to determine the soluble sugar and starch content with the anthrone-sulfuric acid method (Dubois et al., 1956).

paragraphs.title: Ear pedicel, cob and kernel microstructure

div.text: Three maize plants were randomly selected from each treatment at the silking stage in 2019. The ear cob (about 2∼3 cm from the base of ear) and upper of ear pedicel (the joint between the ear cob and pedicel) were excised from each plant (Fig. 7E). In addition, the middle kernels of maize on 3, 8 and 13 DAS were sampled. The ear pedicel, cob and three random grains immediately transferred to fixative (750 mL L -1 ethanol is mixed with equal volume 250 mL L -1 acetic acid). The sample was stained with safranin o-fast green for scanning electron microscopy (Hitachi S-3400 N, Tokyo, Japan). The area and number of vascular bundle were measured with an Olympus BX51 microscope (Olympus China Co., Ltd., Beijing, China) according to the method by He et al. (2007). The starch granule was analyzed using the CaseViewer 2.0 software (3DHISTECH Ltd., Hungary). Twenty endosperm cells were randomly selected from cross-section within the plane of the image in each treatment with four replications. The starch granule number in each endosperm cell was recorded.

Statistical analyses were carried out with SPSS 17.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). The least significant difference was used to determine treatment differences at a P < 0.05 level of probability. A mixed ANOVA model was used to assess the overall source variability in year, hybrid and treatment. SigmaPlot 10.0 was used to obtain the figures.

paragraphs.title: Kernel numbers per spike and three determinants

div.text: In the natural condition (CK treatment), the final KNS averaged 469 for Zhengdan 958 and 349 for Demeiya 1 in two years (Fig. 2). For both hybrids, KNS in the stress treatment was all decreased significantly compared with CK. As an average in two years, the KNS in DS treatment was decreased by 26.2 % compared with CK for Zhengdan 958 while it was reduced by 15.1 % in HS treatment and 48.7 % in DHS treatment.

To identify the critical stage for the response of the kernel set with the stress, three phases including the decrease of floret and exposed silk, pollination failure, and kernel abortion was analyzed. For two hybrids in two years, the decrease percent during the 3rd phase (seed setting) in all stress treatments compared with CK was much higher than the earlier two phases (Fig. 3, Supplemental Table S1). Compared with CK, seed number was decreased by 29.9 % in DS treatment, 22.5 % in HS treatment and 52.3 % in DHS treatment for Zhengdan 958. For Demeiya 1, it was reduced by 30.6 % in DS treatment, 19.0 % in HS treatment and 44.7 % in DHS treatment.

paragraphs.title: Floret, exposed silk and pollination in the 1st and 2nd phases

div.text: Floret number in the 1st phase was reduced by 11.9 % in DS treatment for both hybrids compared with CK (Fig. 3). In HS treatment, it was reduced by 4.6 % for Zhengdan 958 and 4.8 % for Demeiya 1. In DHS treatment, floret number was decreased by 18.7 % for Zhengdan 958 and 16.6 % for Demeiya 1. During the 2nd phase, the number of fertilized florets was reduced by 24.2 % for Zhengdan 958 and 22.6 % for Demeiya 1 in DS treatment. It was reduced by 12.9 % for Zhengdan 958 and 8.2 % for Demeiya 1 in HS treatment. In DHS treatment, the number of fertilized florets was decreased by 32.4 % for Zhengdan 958 and 27.5 % for Demeiya 1.

No significant effect for the fresh weight of exposed silk was observed in HS treatment compared with CK with the exception of Demeiya 1 in 2018 (Fig. 4). For DS treatment, the fresh weight of exposed silk was decreased by 25.1 % for Zhengdan 958 while it was decreased by 31.6 % in DHS treatment. For Demeiya 1, it was reduced by 35.9 % in DS treatment and 31.8 % in DHS treatment. Furthermore, the silk growth rate was inhibited in both years at the early silking stage. For Zhengdan 958 in DS and DHS treatments, silk growth rate was deceased in 1∼5 d after silking while it was decreased in 1∼4 d after silking for Demeiya 1. The fresh weight of exposed silk and silk number was positively correlated with the final KNS (Supplemental Fig. S1).

Differently with the exposed silk, larger effects of pollen viability by heat than drought was observed for two hybrids (Fig. 4). Between CK and DS treatments, similar pollen viability for Zhengdan 958 in 2018 and Demeiya 1 in 2019 was observed. Compared with HS treatment, similar or further decrease of pollen viability was observed in DHS treatment. Compared with CK, pollen viability in DS, HS and DHS for Zhengdan 958 was reduced by 3.2 %, 5.4 % and 10.1 % in 2018, respectively. It was reduced by 3.8 %, 25.3 %, and 23.3 % in 2019, respectively. For Demeiya 1, it was reduced by 5.9 %, 9.7 %, and 12.9 % in 2018, respectively. In 2019, it was reduced by 1.3 %, 19.4 %, and 28.0 %, respectively.

The stress treatments prolonged the anthesis-silking interval (ASI) significantly for both hybrids in two years (Fig. 4). The extended ASI in different treatments followed the order of HS ≤ DS ≤ DHS. For Zhengdan 958, ASI was extended to 2.3∼3.0 days in the stress treatments while it was extended to 1.5∼2.4 days for Demeiya 1.

3.3. 13 C isotope labeling, soluble sugar and starch contents, starch granule numbers and vascular bundle area in the 3rd phase Ear leaves were fed with 13 CO 2 after the pollination, and assimilates with 13 C by the 14th leaf was transported to the ear. 13 C content in the leaf and ear was similar or even higher in stress treatments compared with CK (Fig. 5 A). In the leaf, 13 C content in DHS treatment was higher for Zhengdan 958 compared with other treatments. In the ear, 13 C content in DHS treatment was higher compared with others for Demeiya 1. For Zhengdan 958, the soluble sugar content was increased in both heat and drought treatments in the ear and kernel (Fig. 5B). In contrast, the soluble sugar content was decreased by 3 % in the ear and 6 % in the kernel under DHS treatment compared with CK. For Demeiya 1, the stresses significantly increased soluble sugar content in both ear and kernel. In the kernel, the soluble sugar content in DS, HS and DHS treatment was improved by 20.8 %, 17.9 %, and 22.0 %, respectively.

For both hybrids, starch content in the kernel was in the order of CK > HS > DS > DHS (Fig. 5C). In contrast with the higher soluble sugar content in kernel in both DS and HS treatments for Zhengdan 958, starch content in the kernel was decreased by 44 % in DS treatment and 27 % in HS treatment compared with CK. It was further decreased by 54 % in DHS treatment. Similarly, starch content in kernel was decreased by 42 % in DS treatment, 30 % in HS treatment and 61 % in DHS treatment for Demeiya 1.

The stress treatments significantly affected the development of starch granule including both the starch granule numbers per endosperm cell and starch granule size (Fig. 6, Supplemental Fig. S4). According to the measurements of the 3rd, 8th, 13th DAS, Both starch granule numbers and starch content per endosperm cell was in the order of CK > HS ≥ DS ≥ DHS. For the starch granule size, it was in the order of CK > HS > DS ≥ DHS.

The area of the big vascular bundle in the ear pedicel was decreased by stress treatment for two hybrids with the exception of HS treatment (Fig. 7A). For the area of big vascular bundle in the ear cob, it was decreased by 29 % in DS treatment and 21 % in DHS treatment for Zhengdan 958, while it was increased by 23.0 % in DS treatment, 21.6 % in HS treatment and 15.6 % in DHS treatment for Demeiya 1 (Fig. 7B). A similar or even higher vascular bundle number per square mm was observed in stress treatments compared with CK for both hybrids (Fig. 7C,D).

Among the three consecutive processes around flowering based on a 2-year field experiment, we found the effect of drought and heat stress on the 3rd phase (seed setting) was larger than the other two phases in both hybrids (Fig. 4). Meanwhile, the combined drought and heat stress had the most considerable effects on the three processes, followed by drought and heat stress (Fig. 8).

paragraphs.title: The mechanism of kernel abortion in the seed setting process

div.text: Reducing kernel abortion has been suggested as the most critical target for increasing KNS to improve maize yield (Edreira et al., 2011). At present, multiple underlying mechanisms may contribute to the eventual reproductive failure. For example, there are three kinds of explanation about kernel abortion induced by carbon. First, kernel abortion was caused by limited assimilates. In support of this theory, the sucrose fed to stem partially reversed drought-induced kernel abortion because the glucose, starch and glucose gradient was generally distributed in the ovaries (Mclaughlin and Boyer, 2004;Ruan et al., 2010;Shen et al., 2018). Second, kernel abortion occurred because sugar-to-starch synthesis was disturbed even with an adequate sucrose supply (Cheikh and Jones, 1995;Zinselmeier et al., 1999). Third, recent studies have demonstrated that the expansive growth of reproductive organs is the primary event leading to kernel abortion, rather than a disruption of carbon metabolism in mild water deficits (Oury et al., 2016b;Turc and Tardieu, 2018).

In the present study, the kernel abortion in DS and HS treatments was apparently not a result of limited soluble sugars productivity (Fig. 5). 13 C labeled carbohydrate content in leaf and ear was not significantly decreased in the stress treatment even with higher soluble sugar content in the ear and kernel (Fig. 5A). However, the starch content in the kernel was reduced by 42 % in DS treatment, 29 % in HS treatment and 58 % in DHS treatment as an average in two hybrids, which indicated the limitations in the utilization of available sugars in kernels due to stresses. This reduction in the stress may result from the reduced activity of acid invertase and prevented sucrose from being cleaved (Zinselmeier et al., 1999). Furthermore, it can also assume that the activity of enzymes decreased and relative expression level of genes reduced in sucrose and starch turnover (Duke and Doehlert, 1996;Hurkman et al., 2003;Ning et al., 2018). The lower starch granule numbers per endosperm cell and smaller starch granules size in stresses after the fertilization completed further confirmed the view (Fig. 7, Supplemental Fig. S3). In contrast, a previous study showed there was a location along the phloem-endosperm pathway where the sugar flux resulted in a localized depletion and this concentration was what triggered the response (Makela et al., 2005).

The photoassimilate has to travel a long distance from the source to  sink in maize (Ning et al., 2018). Initially, the sucrose in the leaves was diffused to vascular parenchyma cells from bundle sheath through plasmodesmata (Braun and Slewinski, 2009). Then the sucrose is exported from vascular parenchyma cells to the apoplast by SWEETs (Chen and Thelen, 2010). At the last step, the sucrose was retrieved from the apoplast and loaded into phloem companion cells by sucrose transporters (Baker et al., 2016). When the sucrose loaded into the phloem, the long-distance transport can be impaired by callose deposition (Ma et al., 2008). The previous researches indicated that the kernel abortion was due to a decreased assimilate flux toward the ear and slower transfer of photosynthate to the ear (Mclaughlin and Boyer, 2004;Suwa et al., 2010). In the present study, the soluble sugar and 13 C labeled carbohydrate content in the kernel was similar or even higher in DS and HS treatments compared with CK. It can also suggest that the sucrose transport from mesophyll cell to bundle sheath, to vascular parenchyma cells, to phloem was not influenced significantly. For DHS treatment in Zhengdan 958, the lower soluble sugar in the kernel may be due to the decrease of transport from ear pedicel to the kernel because the big vascular bundle area in the ear cob was significantly reduced by 21 % (Fig. 7).

In this study, we found that the decrease in final KNS was mainly caused by kernel abortion due to lower utilization of soluble sugar resulted from the interfering in starch synthesis. Meanwhile, we found that silk development is more sensitive to drought while pollen activity is more sensitive to high temperature, which was consistent with Lizaso et al. (2018). This also implicated the future breeding program should be considered according to the different crop growth environment (Siebert and Ewert, 2014).

The drought has been becoming more severe in temporal and spatial and decreasing crop production. In this study, drought stress affected the traits related to silk significantly. First, the number of floret in both hybrids was decreased in DS treatment (Fig. 3). The loss of floret number may be related to inadequate assimilate availability of ear (Borrás and Vitantonio-Mazzini 2018). Second, the number of exposed silk was significantly decreased by in DS treatment but were not significantly affected in HS treatment (Fig. 3). Previous studies found the exposed silk was closely related to KNS (Edreira et al., 2011). The reduction of exposed silk numbers was attributed to reduced silk elongation rate in abiotic stresses (Jacobs and Pearson, 1991;Bassetti and Westgate, 1993). Third, the decrease of the silk growth rate extended the ASI to some extent, and the effect of DS treatment on ASI was higher than HS treatment (Fig. 4B). Therefore, more attention should be paid on biomass partitioning to ear, silk development and ASI for droughttolerant maize hybrid breeding (Cooper et al., 2014).

Equally important, heat is another significant stress to limit crop growth and yield. Many pieces of evidence from wheat and rice showed that extreme heat reduced the reproductive organ viability and disrupted the fertilization process (Saini et al., 1983;Sarwar et al., 2017). We also found that heat had a great impact on pollen viability (Fig. 4D). The decrease of pollen viability under HS treatment resulted from the abnormal development of anthers and pollen grains (Giorno et al., 2013), changed pollen morphology (Firon et al., 2006), and reduced starch content in the pollen (Wang et al., 2019). Meanwhile, heat stress can severely inhibit pollen germination as well as pollen tube growth, and disrupt the fertilization process (Young et al., 2004). Therefore, the maize hybrids growing with a heat environment should pay more attention to pollen viability and fertilization process for breeders. In production, appropriate management measures might be employed to decrease the extent of drought and heat stress in the field (Sacks et al., 2009; Siebert and Ewert, 2012;Sharma et al., 2018;Hunt et al., 2019). For example, the integrated soil-crop system management could mitigate the drought and heat stress for maize production in the current and future climate (Meng et al., 2018).

As drought and heat stresses are the prime abiotic constraints under the current and climate change scenario in the future, dissecting the critical stage for maize kernel set in these stresses around flowering was important. In this study, we found that among the three critical phases of kernel development, the third phase, corresponding to seed setting was the main contributor to decreases in final kernel numbers. Furthermore, the kernel abortion in stress can be alleviated through a higher utilization ability for available sugars and starch synthesis at an early stage of seed development. Such the finding in this experiment, along with an effective agronomic management system, would pave the way in developing crop genotypes with improved KNS under drought and heat stress.
